query: Trace the historical progression of Kuiper Belt discovery and exploration, identifying key figures, technological advancements, and specific objects studied by spacecraft.
actual_output: David Jewitt and Jane Luu used a CCD camera attached to a 2.2-meter telescope in Hawaii to discover the first Kuiper Belt Object (KBO), 1992 QB1 (later named Albion). Thousands more KBOs were discovered over the next 25 years.  Pioneer 10 crossed into the Kuiper Belt in 1983. New Horizons was the first spacecraft to visit a KBO, flying by Pluto and its moons in July 2015, and then Arrokoth (2014 MU69) on January 1, 2019.  Neptune's moon Triton and Saturn's moon Phoebe are thought to be captured KBOs, visited by Voyager 2 in 1989 and Cassini in 2004, respectively.  Ground-based telescopes and the Hubble Space Telescope have contributed to Kuiper Belt knowledge.
expected_output: The first Kuiper Belt Object (KBO) discovered was Pluto in 1930, though it wasn't initially recognized as part of a larger population due to its size and brightness relative to later discoveries and the lack of expectation for such a belt. Gerard Kuiper speculated about objects beyond Pluto in 1951, lending his name to the region (sometimes also called the Edgeworth-Kuiper Belt). Kenneth Edgeworth also mentioned such objects in the 1940s. Significant progress occurred in 1992 when David Jewitt and Jane Luu used a large telescope on Mauna Kea equipped with a CCD camera to discover the second KBO, 1992 QB1 (later named Albion). This technological advancement opened the door to finding thousands more KBOs. The first spacecraft to enter the region was Pioneer 10 in 1983, crossing beyond Neptune's orbit. However, NASA's New Horizons was the first mission to visit a KBO, flying past Pluto and its moons in July 2015. It then performed the most distant flyby in history, visiting the KBO Arrokoth (discovered in 2014 using the Hubble Space Telescope) on January 1, 2019, revealing it to be a contact binary and the most primitive object explored by spacecraft.
retrieval_context:
title: Kuiper Belt Exploration and Discoveries
 text:  David Jewitt and Jane Luu attached a CCD camera to a large (2.2-meter) telescope on Mauna Kea in Hawaii, and they quickly detected an object, which was designated 1992 QB1, and later named Albion. Many more discoveries soon followed, with a couple of thousand KBOs being detected over the next quarter-century.
The first spacecraft to enter the Kuiper Belt region was NASA's Pioneer 10 spacecraft when it crossed into the space beyond Neptune's orbit in 1983. But the first spacecraft to visit an object in the Kuiper Belt was New Horizons when it flew by Pluto and its moons. New Horizons then went on to visit Arrokoth.
Two moons of the giant planets are thought to potentially be objects originally from the Kuiper Belt that became captured long ago. Neptune's largest moon Triton was visited by NASA's Voyager 2 spacecraft in 1989, while Phoebe, a small outer moon of Saturn, was visited by NASA's Cassini spacecraft in 2004. Both of these potential captured Kuiper Belt objects orbit their planets in a direction opposite of the other moons and the planet's rotation, which is a strong indication that they likely were captured objects that strayed too close to the planets. Explore in 3D—Eyes on the Solar System Eyes on the Solar System lets you explore the planets, their moons, asteroids, comets and the spacecraft exploring them from 1950 to 2050. Ride with the Curiosity Rover as it lands on Mars or fly by Pluto with the New Horizons spacecraft all from the comfort of your home computer. Kuiper Belt: Exploration Kuiper Belt Home Facts Exploration Stories Multimedia Solar System Home Kuiper Belt: Exploration Introduction Most of what we know about the Kuiper Belt comes from ground-based telescopes and the Hubble Space Telescope . Only one spacecraft has visited the Kuiper Belt. NASA’s New Horizons flew past Pluto in July 2015 – sending back the first clear, close-up images of the tiny world. On Jan. 1, 2019, the spacecraft flew by a Kuiper Belt object later named Arrokoth . In a fitting tribute to the farthest flyby ever conducted by spacecraft, the Kuiper Belt object designated 2014 MU69 was officially named Arrokoth, a Native American term meaning “sky” in the Powhatan/Algonquian language. - More about Arrokoth NASA/Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory/Southwest Research Institute//Roman

Introduction Namesake Potential for Life Size and Distance Orbit and Rotation Moons Rings Formation Structure Surface Atmosphere Magnetosphere Introduction This image showing Pluto's "heart" was taken by NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft on July 13, 2015, when the spacecraft was 476,000 miles (768,000 kilometers) from the surface. 
Credits: NASA/JHUAPL/SwRI
Pluto is a complex and mysterious world with mountains, valleys, plains, craters, and glaciers. It is located in the distant Kuiper Belt. 
Discovered in 1930, Pluto was long considered our solar system's ninth planet. But after the discovery of similar worlds deeper in the Kuiper Belt, Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006 by the International Astronomical Union.

  * Exploration Kuiper Belt Facts The Kuiper Belt is a large, doughnut-shaped region of icy bodies extending far beyond the orbit of Neptune.
The Kuiper Belt is home to Pluto and Arrokoth. Both worlds were visited by NASA's New Horizons spacecraft. There may be millions of other icy worlds in the Kuiper Belt that were left over from the formation of our solar system. Get the Facts These two multiple-exposure images from Hubble show Kuiper Belt Objects against a background of stars in the constellation Sagittarius. The two KBOs are roughly 4 billion miles from Earth.

query: Synthesize NASA's multi-faceted approach to solar system exploration as presented across all the provided texts, detailing the key components like mission types, technological focuses, scientific goals, and targeted celestial bodies.
actual_output: NASA explores the solar system with missions targeting various celestial bodies.  DART, focusing on planetary defense, targeted the Didymos asteroid system (Didymos and its moonlet Dimorphos).  This mission tested asteroid deflection technology by impacting Dimorphos.  Observations of Comet ISON, originating from the Oort Cloud, were made using the International Scientific Optical Network telescope.  NASA also studies dwarf planets like Haumea in the Kuiper Belt, noting its rapid rotation and oval shape.  Additionally, NASA investigates the Sun, its influence on Earth (seasons, ocean currents, weather, etc.), and solar phenomena like sunspots, solar storms, and eclipses.  NASA provides resources for educators, scientists, and citizen scientists related to the Sun.
expected_output: Based on all the provided text, NASA employs a comprehensive solar system exploration strategy involving robotic and human missions, advanced technology development, and broad scientific inquiry. Robotic missions are central, exemplified by orbiters (Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter spotting Curiosity), rovers (Curiosity), telescopes (Hubble, Webb, Roman), sample return missions (OSIRIS-REx to Bennu), and dedicated probes targeting specific bodies (Lucy to Trojan asteroids like Donaldjohanson, Psyche to the metal-rich asteroid). These missions study planets (Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, etc.), moons, asteroids (Bennu, Psyche, Vesta, etc.), comets, the Sun, and the outer reaches like the Kuiper Belt and Oort Cloud. Human spaceflight, centered around the Artemis program, aims for lunar presence (Lunar Space Station module, prepping for Moon landings with hybrid rocket motors) and potentially Mars. Technological development is crucial, focusing on areas like spacesuits (icy chamber tests), propulsion (hybrid rockets, solar-electric for Psyche), communication (ultralight antennas), power (innovative batteries, Power to Explore Challenge), aircraft technology (thin-wing concepts, X-59 supersonic flight), navigation, and instruments for remote sensing and analysis. Scientific goals span understanding planetary formation (via asteroids like Psyche), searching for life (a key driver, though currently only known on Earth), studying Earth's climate and environment (wildfire data, snowmelt tracking), exploring the universe's origins and composition (Big Bang, dark matter/energy), and ensuring planetary defense (tracking NEOs like 2024 YR4 via CNEOS). The agency utilizes a wide range of tools from ground-based observations to spaceborne telescopes and direct exploration spacecraft, leveraging partnerships (e.g., Boeing, ESA, CSA) and engaging the public and STEM community.

Asteroids Home Facts Exploration Featured Asteroids 2024 YR4 Apophis Psyche Bennu Dinkinesh and Selam Donaldjohanson Didymos and Dimorphos Vesta Eros Ida and Dactyl Itokawa Resources Solar System Home Didymos & Dimorphos Overview Asteroid Didymos and its small moonlet Dimorphos make up what’s called a binary asteroid system – meaning the small moon (Dimorphos) orbits the larger body (Didymos).
The two asteroids are not a threat to Earth, but because they do pass relatively close to Earth, they were chosen as the target for NASA’s Double Asteroid Redirection Test (DART) mission – the agency's first mission to test planetary defense technology. This technology could one day be used to deflect hazardous asteroids on a collision course with Earth.
DART deliberately impacted Dimorphos on Sept. 26, 2022. NASA announced on Oct. 11, 2022,that analysis of data obtained by DART’s investigation team showed the spacecraft's kinetic impact with its target asteroid, the moonlet Dimorphos, successfully altered the smaller asteroid’s orbit . This marked the first time humanity had purposely changed the motion of a celestial object, and it was the first full-scale demonstration of asteroid deflection technology. title: Discovery and Naming of Comet ISON
 text:  and the International Space Station observed and detected Comet ISON on the final stretch of its multi-million year journey from the Oort Cloud to the solar corona.
Unable to render the provided source Discovery Russian astronomers Vitali Nevski and Artyom Novichonok discovered the comet with the International Scientific Optical Network 0.4 meter telescope in Kislovodsk, Russia. How This Comet Got Its Name C/2012 S1 (ISON) bears the name of the night-sky survey program that discovered it, the International Scientific Optical Network. ISON is a group of observatories in 10 countries which have organized to detect, monitor, and track objects in space. The network is managed by the Keldysh Institute of Applied Mathematics, part of the Russian Academy of Sciences.
The official International Astronomical Union name of the comet is C/2012 S1 (ISON). Here's how the name breaks down:
  * C indicated ISON it was not expected to return to the inner solar system (even if it had survived its close brush with the Sun's atmosphere in November 2013). Comets that are regular visitors such as comet Halley are designated with P for periodic comets, meaning its orbital period is less than 200 years.
  * 2012 marks the year of discovery.
  * S designates the half month it was discovered in (last half of September).
  * 1 means it was the first discovered in that period.     * NASA HEAT – Educators * Scientists * Citizen Scientists The Sun The Sun is the star at the heart of our solar system. Its gravity holds the solar system together, keeping everything — from the biggest planets to the smallest bits of debris — in its orbit.
20 Active Missions 10 Upcoming Missions Overview The Sun's gravity holds the solar system together, keeping everything – from the biggest planets to the smallest particles of debris – in its orbit. The connection and interactions between the Sun and Earth drive the seasons, ocean currents, weather, climate, radiation belts and auroras. Though it is special to us , there are billions of stars like our Sun scattered across the Milky Way galaxy.
The Sun has many names in many cultures. The Latin word for Sun is “sol
